ar.name: العربية
ar.notes: As of 2024, we have limited Arabic dialectical differentiation, so preference is to use generic code

zh-CN.name: 中文-(简体)
zh-CN.notes: The alternative is to use zh-Hans and zh-Hant - which would delineate Simplified vs. Traditional without any regional association. I think for now we can stick with zh-CN and zh-TW, and perhaps expand to zh-HK if we need to.

nl-NL.name: Nederlands
nl-NL.notes: Using the four letter code for Dutch; Netherlands appears to be our current Dutch-speaking user base

fr.name: Français
fr.notes: For French, we should default to fr for now, until we can parse the differences between France, Canada, and Francophone Africa

de_DE.name: Deutsch
de_DE.notes: German, Germany aligns with our current user base

el-GR.name: Ελληνικά
el-GR.notes: Greek, Greece aligns with our current user base

en-GB.name: English (United Kingdom)
en-GB.notes: English UK is available if needed, esp. to comply with UK regulations

en-US.name: English (United States)
en-US.notes: We use English (United States) as our source locale across products and projects

ha-NG.name: Hausa
ha-NG.notes: Nigerian Hausa is most relevant to our current user base

hi-IN.name: हिन्दी
hi-IN.notes: Hindi, India aligns is a relevant locale code, but more exploration into Indian languages is warranted

hu-HU.name: Magyar
hu-HU.notes: Hungarian, Hungary is the most relevant locale code for our user base

id-ID.name: Bahasa-Indonesia
id-ID.notes: Indonesian, Indonesia is the most relevant locale code for our user base

it-IT.name: italiano
it-IT.notes: Italian, Italy is a relevant locale code for our user base

ja-JP.name: 日本語
ja-JP.notes: Japanese, Japan is a relevant locale code for our user base

ko-KR.name: 한국어
ko-KR.notes: This level of specificity is important because it denotes South Korean Korean separately from North Korea

fa-AF.name: فارسی
fa-AF.notes: This level of specificity is important because it denotes the Persian spoken in Afghanistan separately from the Persian spoken in Iran. There may be implications to including fa-IR because of Iran's presence on the OFAC sanctions list. Also, the Persian spoken in Tajikistan is written in the Cyrillic alphabet

ms-MY.name: Bahasa-Melayu
ms-MY.notes: Malay, Malaysia is relevant to our user base

pcm.name: Pidgin
pcm.notes: This is the best locale code for SEO purposes. I believe Pidgin is a better name to use for the UI than naijá

pl-PL.name: polski
pl-PL.notes: Polish, Poland is most relevant to our user base

pt-BR.name: português-brasil
pt-BR.notes: For now, Brazilian Portugese is the only dialect of Portuguese that we are localizing for

ro-RO.name: română
ro-RO.notes: Romanian, Romania is the most relevant locale to our user base

ru-RU.name: Русский
ru-RU.notes: Russian, Russia represents the largest group of Russian speakers, and the most relevant to our user base

es-419.name: español-latinoamérica
es-419.notes: For now, we are only localizing for Latin American Spanish, so this is the most relevant locale for us to use

tl.name: tagalog
tl.notes: We have gone back and forth about which locale to use to serve our users in the Philippines. Tagalog is the basis for Filipino, the national language of the Philippines. tl is the ISO 639 standard, so we will use this until data indicates otherwise.

th-TH.name: ไทย
th-TH.notes: Thai, Thailand is the most relevant locale for our user base

tr-TR.name: türkçe
tr-TR.notes: Turkish, Turkey is the most relevant locale for our user base

uk-UA.name: Українська
uk-UA.notes: Ukrainian, Ukraine is the most relevant locale for our user base

vi-VN.name: tiếng-việt
vi-VN.notes: Vietnamese, Vietnam is the most relevant locale for our user base
